results.title: Triptych
results.brief_description:
This is the view overlooking Plac Wielkapolski (Great Poland Square), a busy intersection of pedestrian, tram, and other vehicle traffic adjacent to an open-air market. A meditation on an unfamiliar environment by an outside observer, and a response to the work of Zbignew Rybczynski and other members of the Lodz Film Form Workshop of the 1970’s.
In memory of Antoni Mikolajczyk, head of the studio of video and installation, who passed away last spring, a year after this material was shot in his studio. Shot over a twenty four hour period in early Spring 1999, during my stay as a visiting professor at the Poznan’ Academy of Fine Arts Studio of Video and Installation.

results.title: The Adventures of Floss the Fairy and Riddley Robot: the letter Z runs away
results.brief_description: Written and produced by an Early Childhood teacher in Queensland, this tape is aimed at assisting young children in developing literacy and numeracy skills. The video is interactive, allowing young children to discover and learn through literacy and numeracy experiences, and the fantasy story encompasses songs that are supported by 3D visual effects, thus creating a fun learning environment that further develops confidence and success. Areas covered include; spatial and positional word vocabulary and relationships, numbers, the alphabet, fine motor movements, self esteem, music and movement. ‘The Adventures of Floss the Fairy and Riddley Robot’ will entertain and educate children aged 7 months to 7 years.

results.title: Hawkins' rivers
results.creator_credit: Eyelevel Production, TAS Television Productions and Robert Heazlewood
results.brief_description: Leo McKern narrates this modern day adventure set in twentieth century Tasmania. The true story concerns Tasmanian doctor and canoeist John Hawkins, who led the fight to save the Franklin River. It was, and still is a dilemma between developing the natural resources of the land or to forgo development at the price of suffering potential economic, political and social consequences. It is an issue that commanded the rest of the nation’s attention and continues to be pertinent today.

results.title: Max floating to songs
results.brief_description: Stranger Things has introduced Zoomers to another 80s icon: pop star Kate Bush. In season four, Max (Sadie Sink) is saved from villain Vecna’s spell by her friends playing Bush’s “Running Up That Hill”. Not only did the scene shoot the song into Billboard’s top 10 for the first time in 37 years, it’s been adopted by internet users who’ve wondered what song would save them. One Twitter account tried answer that question by remixing contemporary songs into the scene, showing how online ingenuity can bridge the cultural past & present while allowing viewers to participate in moving image making.
results.description:
This video features in a responsive display in the museum that presents the moments, stories and memes capturing the zeitgeist by going viral on the internet.

Stranger Things has introduced Zoomers to another 80s icon: pop star Kate Bush. In season four, Max (Sadie Sink) is saved from villain Vecna’s spell by her friends playing Bush’s “Running Up That Hill”. Not only did the scene shoot the song into Billboard’s top 10 for the first time in 37 years, it’s been adopted by internet users who’ve wondered what song would save them. One Twitter account tried answer that question by remixing contemporary songs into the scene, showing how online ingenuity can bridge the cultural past and present while allowing viewers to participate in moving image making.

Social media users across the internet have also used special effects programs to show themselves levitating, or running out of the Upside Down from Vecna, often to their favourite songs, which they’ve edited into the visuals. This has allowed the scene to spawn numerous meme templates.

The personal element of the narrative - that your favourite song can save you from evil - and the nostalgia of the series lends itself to users contributing their own songs (and associated emotions) to the visuals, creating a personal but collective, shareable experience.

Another prominent meme created from Stranger Things 4 relies on sound. Before claiming his victims, Vecna makes them hallucinate a ticking grandfather clock (among other things) and its ominous chime (used to great effect in horror movies forever) has become an eerie indicator that he’s coming for you. Naturally, TikTokers have appropriated the sound for comedic effect. Know Your Meme traces the first use of it to user @marcusbtv, who hears it in a skit about gaming, removes one headphone and says “Nope….. not getting me”, before going back to playing.

It’s now been repurposed and reused across the internet, with users often engaging with an invisible clock (they’re hallucinating) or even Big Ben.
description_for_label: Stranger Things has introduced Zoomers to another 80s icon: pop star Kate Bush. In season four, Max (Sadie Sink) is saved from villain Vecna’s spell by her friends playing Bush’s “Running Up That Hill”. Not only did the scene shoot the song into Billboard’s top 10 for the first time in 37 years, it’s been adopted by internet users who’ve wondered what song would save them. One Twitter account tried answer that question by remixing contemporary songs into the scene, showing how online ingenuity can bridge the cultural past and present while allowing viewers to participate in moving image making.

results.title: 100 Pages
results.brief_description: ‘100 Pages’ is a project based upon the theme of North Sydney Girls High School’s Centenary. This project used the School’s identity and history as inspiration for artmaking. Through the artmaking, students are celebrating the school’s identity in the present and past community; isolating individual events, subjects and objects as inspiration. The title of the unit, ‘100 Pages’, comes from the initial idea of 100 animations, for 100 years of history. This project has been developed for the Stage 5 elective, Year 10 Photography and Digital Media class (PDM), which comprises 12 students from North Sydney Girls High School.

results.title: 'Screen It' 2015 [winning entries and special mentions]
results.brief_description:
‘Screen It’ was Australia’s national film, animation and game making competition for school-aged students, run by ACMI for 16 years to 2019.

Designed to encourage imagination and inventiveness in primary and secondary school students, ‘Screen It’ fostered a new generation of young media makers. In 2015 budding young film and game-makers took up the challenge of creating their own short film or game in response to the theme “Change”.

Witness first-hand the amazing winning entries of the 2015 Screen It competition!
